issues.description: Constructor signature for Animal is inconsistent between the problem statement UML and the provided/template code. The UML and problem text specify an Animal constructor taking two parameters (Animal(String, int)) and an age attribute, while the template's usage (Main.java) and the solution implement Animal with a single-parameter constructor (Animal(String)) and no age parameter. If students follow the problem statement strictly (two-arg constructor) they will be unable to use the template Main or match the provided solution, and may be blocked from compiling or running the starter code.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the constructor specification consistent across artifacts. Either (A) update the problem statement and UML to require a single-argument constructor Animal(String) (and remove age as an attribute), or (B) update the template and solution to provide and use Animal(String, int) and add the age attribute everywhere (adjust Seal/Pig/Goat constructors and Main invocation accordingly). Choice (A) is the least disruptive given the current template and solution.

issues.description: The problem statement UML declares an 'age: int' attribute for Animal, but neither the template usage nor the solution include this attribute. This mismatch between the stated class attributes and the code students will work with can confuse students about which fields they must implement and initialize.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the attribute list across artifacts. Either remove 'age' from the UML/problem text (and clarify that only 'name' is required), or add an 'age' field to the template and solution Animal class and update all constructors/usages (Seal, Pig, Goat, and Main) to initialize it. Update the problem text to explicitly state which attributes students must initialize to avoid ambiguity.

issues.description: The problem statement's UML and instructions declare that Animal has two attributes (name and age) and an Animal constructor with signature Animal(String, int). However the reference solution's Animal class only defines the name attribute and a single-argument constructor Animal(String) (no age field). The template's Main (example usage) further shows single-argument constructions (e.g., Seal("Clarabelle")), adding ambiguity about which constructor students should implement. This mismatch around the attribute 'age' and the constructor signature creates confusion: students following the UML will implement/initialize an age field and expect a two-argument constructor, while the provided solution and example usage use a one-argument constructor. That inconsistency increases extraneous cognitive load and may cause students to implement constructors/fields that don't match the solution or the provided examples.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the expected Animal API consistent across all artifacts. Either (A) update the solution and template to include an int age field, getters/setters for age, and change constructors to Animal(String, int) (and adjust all subclasses’ constructors and example usages accordingly), or (B) update the problem statement UML and instructions to show a single-argument constructor Animal(String) and remove the age attribute from the UML. Prefer (A) if the learning goal includes working with multiple attributes; otherwise prefer (B) to match the current solution and template.
